gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Atmospheric concentrations of total and dissolved elements and water-soluble ions measured over coastal Namibia in 2017

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Atmospheric concentrations of total and dissolved elements and water-soluble ions measured over coastal Namibia in 2017

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Aerosol particles smaller than 10 µm in aerodynamic diameter (PM10) were collected at the Henties Bay Aerosol Observatory (HBAO) in Namibia by an automated sampler (model Partisol Plus 2025i, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA USA) on 47 mm Whatman Nuclepore polycarbonate filters (1-µm pore size). The air was drawn through a certified sampling inlet (Rupprecht and Patashnick, Albany, New York, USA) located at approximately 30 m above ground and operated at a flow rate of 1 m3 h-1. Samples were collected for 9 hours during the daytime (from 9:00 to 18:00 UTC time) and night-time (21:00 to 06:00 UTC time) for 13 non-consecutive weeks from April to December 2017 (7-14 April, 26 April-3 May, 19-26 May, 07-14 July, 2-9 1ugust, 15-22 August, 18-25 September, 02-09 October, 31 October-7 November, 13-20 November, 28 November-04 December, 12-19 December). In total, 176 samples (including 13 blanks, one per week of sampling) were collected. Analysis of those samples are provided in three datasets. The dataset “Namibia_HBAO_elemental_concentrations_2017.txt“ reports the atmospheric concentrations of 24 elements (Na, Mg, Al, Si, P, S, Cl, K, Ca, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Sr, Pb, Nd, Cd, Ba) obtained by wavelength-dispersive X-ray fluorescence (WD-XRF). The dataset “Namibia_HBAO_water-soluble-ionic_concentrations_2017.txt“ reports the atmospheric concentrations of 16 water-soluble ions measured by Ion Chromatography (IC). The dataset “Namibia_HBAO_dissolved-elemental_concentrations_2017.txt“ reports the atmospheric concentrations of dissolved mass concentrations of 25 water-soluble metals and metalloids obtained by Inductively Coupled Plasma-Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-AES) and by High-resolution Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry (HR-ICP-MS) .

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: SISmalp 2017-2019 - Maurienne seismic swarm catalog – France

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: SISmalp 2017-2019 - Maurienne seismic swarm catalog – France

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: In 2017–2019, a seismic swarm was triggered in the Maurienne valley (French Alps), with more than 5000 events detected by the regional SISmalp network. The population, who asked SISmalp to provide information on the processes and the associated risk, felt many earthquakes. In a post-L’Aquila trial context, we conducted a reflection on the scientific and social operational management of the crisis. The geological and tectonic analysis, the deployment of a temporary seismic network, an automatic double-difference relocation procedure (HypoDD) after clustering earthquakes, as well as the interactions with the population and the risk managers, have been carried out jointly. The length and unpredictability of the sequence complicated crisis management and the relations between local authorities and civil protection. The involvement of SISmalp, beyond its main scientific and observation prerogatives, has contributed to moderate the fears of the population by providing scientific explanations.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Terrain displacement from the Turkiye-Syria earthquakes of February 6, 2023 obtained with the GDM-OPT-ETQ service applied on Sentinel-2 optical imagery

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Terrain displacement from the Turkiye-Syria earthquakes of February 6, 2023 obtained with the GDM-OPT-ETQ service applied on Sentinel-2 optical imagery

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
The region along the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) has a well-known history of seismic activity. On February 6, 2023, two earthquakes of Mw 7.8 and 7.5 had devastating effects on the ground by opening large ruptures and by displacing the earth crust of 5 to 10 m locally. The longer of the two ruptures stretches nearly 300 km in the northeastern direction from the northeastern part of the Mediterranean Sea. The surface rupture was created by the first and most powerful 7.8-magnitude earthquake that triggered at 4:17 am local time; the second surface rupture of 125 km long opened during the second 7.5-magnitude earthquake about nine hours later.
By comparing several optical satellite imagery before and after the earthquake, the horizontal displacements of the ground can be calculated using image correlation (also known as offset tracking) techniques. This data release contains co-seismic horizontal displacements obtained from the analysis of Copernicus Sentinel-2 satellite imagery at 10 m spatial resolution. The dataset has been created with the GDM-OPT-ETQ service (Provost et al., 2022) of the ForM@Ter solid Earth data hub using the open source photogrammetry library MicMac (Rosu et al., 2015, Rupnik et al., 2018). The massive processing was performed on the Geohazard Exploitation Platform (GEP).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Large synthesis of in situ field measurements of the size distribution of mineral dust aerosols across their lifecycle-MRT

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Large synthesis of in situ field measurements of the size distribution of mineral dust aerosols across their lifecycle-MRT

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Collection of particle size distribution of atmospheric mineral dust particles representative of mid−range transport conditions (MRT, 1−4 days after emission; number of datasets N=36). Data are reported as volume size distributions (dV/dlogD) versus geometrical diameter. The name of each dataset indicate the original reference publication, sometimes with indication of a specific technique. Level−1 (LEV1) data are obtained by interpolating raw data (LEV0) over a common size range of equi−logarithmically spaced diameters (dlogD = 0.05) encompassing the original diameter range for each dataset. Level-2a (LEV2a) data, based on LEV1, harmonize the size distributions by converting the operational original particle diameters, which depend on the physical principle of each instrument, into a common–defined sphere−equivalent geometric diameter. Level−2b (LEV2b), based on LEV1, harmonize the size distributions by converting the operational original particle diameters into a common–defined geometrical diameter by taking into account that mineral dust is aspherical. Each dataset is normalized so that the integral is equal to 1 over a common diameter range. The diameter range for integral normalization was set to be the largest as possible and to be covered by more than 90% of the datasets in each category. For MRT data this common range for integral normalization is 0.71 and 8.9 µm. Statistical metrics (mean, median, 25% and 75% percentiles, and standard deviation) are provided. Full details are provided in Formenti and Di Biagio (2024) (main manuscript and supplementary information).

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Large synthesis of in situ field measurements of the size distribution of mineral dust aerosols across their lifecycle-SOURCE
Large synthesis of in situ field measurements of the size distribution of mineral dust aerosols across their lifecycle-SOURCE

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Collection of in situ measurements of particle size distribution of atmospheric mineral dust particles representative of emission/source conditions (SOURCE, <1 day from emission; number of datasets N=12). Data are reported as volume size distributions (dV/dlogD) versus geometrical diameter. The name of each dataset indicate the original reference publication, sometimes with indication of a specific technique. Level−1 (LEV1) data are obtained by interpolating raw data (LEV0) over a common size range of equi−logarithmically spaced diameters (dlogD = 0.05) encompassing the original diameter range for each dataset. Level-2a (LEV2a) data, based on LEV1, harmonize the size distributions by converting the operational original particle diameters, which depend on the physical principle of each instrument, into a common–defined sphere−equivalent geometric diameter. Level−2b (LEV2b), based on LEV1, harmonize the size distributions by converting the operational original particle diameters into a common–defined geometrical diameter by taking into account that mineral dust is aspherical. Each dataset is normalized so that the integral is equal to 1 over a common diameter range. The diameter range for integral normalization was set to be the largest as possible and to be covered by more than 90% of the datasets in each category. For SOURCE data this common range for integral normalization is 1.58-7.1 µm. Statistical metrics (mean, median, 25% and 75% percentiles, and standard deviation) are provided. Full details are provided in Formenti and Di Biagio (2024) (main manuscript and supplementary information).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: SISMalp-1987-2023: The catalogue of 1987-2023 earthquakes in the western (French) Alps and Rhône valley north of 43.5°N

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: SISMalp-1987-2023: The catalogue of 1987-2023 earthquakes in the western (French) Alps and Rhône valley north of 43.5°N

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The western Alpine belt is the focal point of moderate but constant seismic activity. Numerous geodynamic and seismological studies underline the many scientific questions linked to Alpine dynamic processes and the associated rate of deformation resulting from late continental collision phases, and the assessment of seismic hazard and its associated risks. Seismic monitoring in the northern French Alps was launched in 1987 with the installation of the first seismological network, hosted by the Earth Science Observatory at Grenoble Alpes University. Since then, the network has been updated over the years, keeping pace with technical developments in seismic instrumentation, monitoring and data management. The homogenization of information described in this scientific data paper is motivated by the need for a single instrumental seismic catalogue. The final catalogue SISMalp-1987-2023 contains 50,822 earthquakes with completeness magnitude lower than 1; it can serve as a basis for all general seismotectonic and risk assessment studies in the region.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: A new high spatial density temperature dataset in the Grenoble alpine valley (France) for urban heat island investigation and climate services dedicated to municipalities purposes

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: A new high spatial density temperature dataset in the Grenoble alpine valley (France) for urban heat island investigation and climate services dedicated to municipalities purposes

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Within the study of the urban heat island (UHI) in Echirolles and Grenoble (France), two temperature measurement networks have been deployed. The aim is to measure the temperature gradients associated with the UHI in summer. A total of 64 measurement points have been installed in the various neighborhoods on 3-meter-high streetlights, starting in summer 2019. The preliminary classification of the various neighborhood typologies according to "Local Climate Zone" guided the choice of location for the temperature sensors. These urban observations respond to a dual challenge: firstly, to observe temperature located in complex topographical situations with valleys, and secondly, to observe the urban climate in neighborhoods where social considerations are important. The municipalities of Echirolles and Grenoble were involved in the investigation. The ADEME-funded CASSANDRE research program analyzes and processes these observations to study the vulnerability of inhabitants to heat waves and more generally to summer heat stress (https://www.ige-grenoble.fr/CASSANDRE).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: 3-D velocity models of Western Europe from surface wave tomography

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: 3-D velocity models of Western Europe from surface wave tomography

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: We provide two large-scale 3D shear-wave velocity models of the crust and upper mantle from surface wave imaging using AlpArray ambient noise data: 1) Eucrust_transD-ANT, Lithospheric transdimensional ambient-noise tomography of W-Europe: implications for crustal-scale geometry of the W-Alps (Nouibat et al., 2022); 2) AlpsLig-crust_WET, Ambient-noise wave-equation tomography of the Alps and Ligurian-Provence basin (Nouibat et al., 2023). Both models were developed as part of the PhD thesis of A. Nouibat (2019-2022, ISTerre - Université Grenoble Alpes), funded by the SEISCOPE consortium (http://seiscope2.osug.fr) and the RGF program (Référentiel Géologique de la France, http://rgf.brgm.fr/).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: High-resolution co-seismic fault offsets of the 2023 Türkiye earthquake ruptures using satellite imagery

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: High-resolution co-seismic fault offsets of the 2023 Türkiye earthquake ruptures using satellite imagery

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: On February 6, 2023, southern Türkiye was struck by two large earthquakes at 01:17 UTC (Mw=7.8, Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş) and 10:30 UTC (Mw=7.6, Elbistan, Kahramanmaraş), causing severe damage at the complex junction of the Dead Sea Fault (DSF), the Cyprus Arc and the East Anatolian Fault Zone (EAFZ). The ruptures propagated along several known strands of the southwestern termination of the EAFZ, the main Pazarcık and Karasu valley faults, and the Çardak-Sürgü fault. Here we present the high-resolution mapping of the entire coseismic surface rupture and an estimate of the rupture width, total and on-fault offset, and diffuse deformation obtained a few days to three months after the two mainshocks. The mapping is derived from image correlation of Sentinel-2 optical satellite imagery and validated with offset measurements collected on the ground. We find that the ruptures extend over lengths of 310 km and 140 km for the Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.6 mainshocks, respectively. The maximum offsets reach 7.5 ± 0.8 m and 8.7 ± 0.8 m near the epicenters of the Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.6 events, respectively. We propose a segmentation of the two ruptures based on these observations, and further discuss the location of the potential supershear rupture. The use of optical image correlation, complemented by field investigations along earthquake faults, provides new insights into seismic hazard assessment.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Strength of TROPOMI Satellite Observations in Retrieving Hourly Resolved Sources of Volcanic Sulfur Dioxide by Inverse Modeling

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Strength of TROPOMI Satellite Observations in Retrieving Hourly Resolved Sources of Volcanic Sulfur Dioxide by Inverse Modeling

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Volcanic eruptions release sulfur dioxide (SO2) gas, affecting air quality, ecosystems, aviation, and potentially climate. To comprehensively assess these atmospheric effects as well as local volcanic hazards, high-temporal-resolution information on SO2 mass flux and injection height is crucial and can be delivered on an hourly basis by inverse modeling. We show here the strength of assimilating high-spatial-resolution SO2 column measurements from Sentinel-5P/TROPOMI hyperspectral observations, compared to coarser resolution Suomi-NPP/OMPS data, through inverse modeling using the CHIMERE Eulerian chemistry-transport model. As a case study, we investigate the dynamics of the 2018 Ambrym eruption (December 13–18, Vanuatu) starting with the extrusion of an intra-caldera lava flow, coinciding with lava lake draining, followed by the lateral propagation of a voluminous intrusion of magma triggering a submarine eruption. Prior to this eruption marking the end of a decades-long sustained passive degassing associated to lava lake activity, Ambrym held the distinction of top ranking volcanic SO2 emitters in the world. The assimilation of TROPOMI data by inverse modeling proves efficient for accurately characterizing Ambrym SO2 emissions during periods of intense degassing that can be strongly underestimated with OMPS data. We show that this advantage relies on the high spatial resolution of TROPOMI observations which allows for robustly capturing near-source highly concentrated SO2 plumes emitted a few hours before satellite overpass. TROPOMI measurements, also facilitate the detection of volcanic SO2 even at the noisy swath edges, thanks to a superior signal-to-noise ratio and less pixel geometric distortion than OMPS. This distinctive attribute of TROPOMI has enabled the characterization of pre-eruptive SO2 emissions missed by OMPS. Moreover, our inverse modeling procedure effectively discerns, and traces hidden SO2 plumes beneath clouds by assimilating SO2 column data from successive satellite overpasses, hence mitigating satellite retrieval limitations. Furthermore, this approach proves to be less susceptible to interference from ash emissions, as compared to flux estimation derived from near-source observations by the geostationary Himawari-8/AHI sensor. Our study unveils that the 2018 Ambrym eruption discharged approximately 42 +/-16 kt (by OMPS) to 52+/-13 kt (by TROPOMI) of SO2 during the event. The hourly-resolved SO2 flux time series retrieved by inverse modeling sheds light on the eruption’s progression, pinpointing distinct sources of SO2 emissions from either lava flow or shallow magma intrusions. In summary, the assimilation of TROPOMI data into inverse modeling procedures holds substantial promise for advancing our comprehension of magma transport and the environmental repercussions associated with volcanic eruptions.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Chronology of sedimentation and landscape evolution in the Okavango Rift Zone, a developing young rift in southern Africa

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Chronology of sedimentation and landscape evolution in the Okavango Rift Zone, a developing young rift in southern Africa

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Kalahari Basin in southern Africa, shaped by subsidence and epeirogeny, features the Okavango Rift Zone (ORZ) as a significant structural element characterized by diffused extensional deformation forming a prominent depocenter. This study elucidates the Pleistocene landscape evolution of the ORZ by examining the chronology of sediment formation and filling this incipient rift and its surroundings. Modeling of cosmogenic nuclide concentrations in surficial eolian sand from distinct structural blocks around the ORZ provides insights into sand’s residence time on the surface. Sand formation occurred from ~2.2 to 1.1 Ma, coinciding with regional tectonic events. Notably, provenance analyses of sand within ORZ's lowermost block where large alluvial fans are found indicate different source rocks and depositional environments than those of the eolian sands found at a higher elevation. This suggests that the major phase of rift subsidence and the following incision of alluvial systems into the rift occurred after eolian dune formation. Luminescence dating reveals that deposition in alluvial fan settings in the incised landscape began not later than ~250 ka, and that a lacustrine environment existed since at least ~140 ka. The established chronological framework constrains the geomorphological effects of the different tectono-climatic forces that shaped this nascent rifting area. It highlights two pronounced stages of landscape development, with the most recent major deformation event in the evolving rift probably occurring during the middle Pleistocene transition (1.2-0.75 Ma). This event is reflected as a striking change in the depositional environments due to the configurational changes accompanying rift progression.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: INTERSEISMIC AND LONG-TERM DEFORMATION OF SOUTHEASTERN SICILY DRIVEN BY THE IONIAN SLAB ROLL-BACK

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: INTERSEISMIC AND LONG-TERM DEFORMATION OF SOUTHEASTERN SICILY DRIVEN BY THE IONIAN SLAB ROLL-BACK

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: New satellite geodetic data challenge our knowledge of the deformation mechanisms driving the active deformations affecting Southeastern Sicily. The PS-InSAR measurements evidence a generalized subsidence and an eastward tilting of the Hyblean Plateau combined with a local relative uplift along its eastern coast. To find a mechanical explanation for the present-day strain field, we investigate short and large-scale surface-to-crustal deformation processes. Geological and geophysical data suggest that the southward migration of the Calabrian subduction could be the causative geodynamic process

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Timeseries of the snow surface temperature acquired at the Col du Lautaret (French Alps) during two winter seasons with an uncooled thermal infrared camera

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Timeseries of the snow surface temperature acquired at the Col du Lautaret (French Alps) during two winter seasons with an uncooled thermal infrared camera
Timeseries of the snow surface temperature acquired at the Col du Lautaret (French Alps) during two winter seasons with an uncooled thermal infrared camera

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains maps of the surface temperature of snow acquired at the Col du Lautaret (45.0347 N, 6.4051 E, 2057 m a.s.l.) acquired every 2 minutes during winter 2021-2022 and spring 2023 with an Optris PI640i thermal infrared camera. The dataset also includes timeseries of RGB images of the scene acquired every 10 minutes during operation of the TIR camera, timeseries of the surface temperature, incoming longwave radiation, air temperature, air humidity and wind speed acquired every 30 seconds at two distinct points in the camera’s field of view (AWS-North, 45.0317 N 6.3948 E, and AWS-South, 45.0335 N 6.3950) and the TIR camera’s internal temperature. Images were acquired between 2021-11-20 and 2022-05-12 during the first season, and between 2023-02-10 and 2023-05-24 during the second season. The images were filtered for foggy and snowy conditions, processed radiometrically and orthoprojected on a digital elevation model. The result is 130019 maps with 464x506 pixels at 2 m resolution in the EPSG:32632 projection. The maps are singleband and the surface temperature data is in float32 format.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Streamflow monitoring at high temporal resolution based on non-contact instruments in the Galabre river (Southern pre-Alps, France)

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Streamflow monitoring at high temporal resolution based on non-contact instruments in the Galabre river (Southern pre-Alps, France)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
We provide a dataset for calculating streamflow in a river of the Southern pre-Alps in France over the period October 2018 to May 2021. The river is called the Galabre and is a tributary of the Bès, which in turn is a tributary of the Bléone. The hydrometric station, so-called RIPLE, which incorporates non-contact instruments, was described in detail by Nord et al (2020). It was installed at a site subject to frequent bathymetric changes, 2.5 km downstream of a historic hydrometric station called « La Robine », at the "Galabre" site of the Draix-Bléone observatory (https://draixbleone.osug.fr/). The dataset combines high-frequency monitoring (every 10 minutes) of water level and surface water velocity using radar, ground-based bathymetric surveys, video sequences recorded by fixed camera with velocity fields obtained using the Fudaa-LSPIV software (https://forge.irstea.fr/projects/fudaa-lspiv), and the results of theoretical models of velocity field distribution in the river section.
Nord, G., Michielin, Y., Biron, R., Esteves, M., Freche, G., Geay, T., et al. (2020). An autonomous low-power instrument platform for monitoring water and solid discharges in mesoscale rivers. Geoscientific Instrumentation, Methods and Data Systems, 9(1), 41–67. https://doi.org/10.5194/gi-9-41-2020

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Eucrust_transD-ANT

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Eucrust_transD-ANT is a new lithospheric-scale 3-D model of Western Europe derived from ambient noise tomography (ANT). This ANT makes use of vertical-component noise correlations computed between 950 permanent stations and 600 temporary stations from the AlpArray sea-land seismic network and the Cifalps and EASI linear arrays. 2-D group-velocity maps from 4 to 150 s are computed using a transdimensional (transD) Bayesian inversion of Rayleigh-wave traveltimes. Using a probabilistic approach, the local dispersion curves and their uncertainties are inverted at depth to derive a quasi-3-D model that is further refined using a linearized inversion. This resulting Vs model highlights strong along-strike variations of the lithospheric structure, particularly in the subduction complex between the European and Adriatic plates. For more details, please refer to Nouibat et al., 2022 (DOI: 10.1093/gji/ggab520).

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Waveform data used to produce this model belong to the permanent networks with codes AC, BE (Royal Observatory Of Belgium 1985), CA (Institut Cartogrà fic I Geològic De Catalunya - Institut D’Estudis Catalans 1984), CH [Swiss Seismological Service (SED) at Swiss Seismological Service (SED) At ETH Zurich (1983)], CR (University Of Zagreb 2001)), CZ (Institute Of Geophysics Of The Academy Of Sciences Of The Czech Republic 1973), ES (Instituto Geografico Nacional, Spain 1999), FR ((RESIF, RESIF 1995), G [(Institut de Physique du Globe de Paris (IPGP) & Ecole et Observatoire des Sciences de la Terre de Strasbourg (EOST) 1982)], GB [(GEOFON Data Centre 1993)], GR [(Federal Institute for Geosciences & Natural Resources (BGR) 1976)], IV ((INGV Seismological Data Centre 2006)), NL (KNMI 1993), OE (ZAMG-Zentralanstalt Für Meterologie Und Geodynamik 1987), SL (Slovenian Environment Agency 2001) and UP (SNSN 1904). We also used data of the temporary AlpArray network (AlpArray Seismic Network 2015), Cifalps (YP network, Zhao et al. 2016) and XT network Zhao et al. 2018) and EASI experiments (XT network, AlpArray Seismic Network 2014).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: QuakeML and sc3ML files for Maurienne seismic swarm

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: QuakeML and sc3ML files for Maurienne seismic swarm

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset is a seismic event catalog for the Maurienne seismic swarm (2017-2019). The catalog was produced based on a regional seismological permanent network, and a local temporary network. It includes: - 2 localisations for each event: 1) the classical Seiscomp3 location, and 2) the relocation computed using HypoDD, produced for events grouped by clusters. - Pick information and magnitudes from Seiscomp3 - Cluster number - Focal mechanisms calculated using the IRIS focmec package, for the 41 largest events (magnitude higher or equal to 2.4).

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Input data used to produce this catalog is seismological data from velocimeter stations within 50km of the seismic swarm. Stations from several seismological networks were used (codes : FR, Z3, RA), and a post-seismic temporary network composed of 5 stations (code : YW) was deployed to densify locally the network and improve the accuracy and completeness of data acquired. All data was transfered to the Institut des Sciences de la Terre (ISTerre, Grenoble, France) analysis centre in near-real time. The waveform data and metadata associated are injected in near-real time in a seiscomp instance (https://www.seiscomp.de/) to automatically detect and locate earthquakes. A member of the team of seismologists then manually refines and validates the automatic analysis. The resulting seiscomp database is the first source of information included in the catalog. A second type of information in the catalog was produced after further analysis : based on the events detected in the area with seiscomp, we created event clusters based on high waveform cross-correlations. The events of each cluster were relocated finely using the dedicated package hypoDD (https://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~felixw/hypoDD.html). The cluster number and resulting hypocenter coordinates were included in the catalog. Finally, for the 41 largest events (magnitude higher or equal to 2.4), the focal mechanism was computed using IRIS’s focmec package (https://seiscode.iris.washington.edu/projects/focmec). This information is also included in the catalog.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Total columns measurements of CO2 in Mexico-City

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Total columns measurements of CO2 in Mexico-City
Total columns measurements of CO2 in Mexico-City

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Seven solar-viewing Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometers were deployed during an intensive 7-month field campaign (part of the French-Mexican project MERCI-CO2) in the MCMA area during October 2020 to May 2021. One FTIR has been continuously operated since 2012 from an NDACC station (Altzomoni Atmospheric Observatory) located on a mountain top (3,985 m a.s.l), which is 60 km from Mexico City. This high-resolution IFS 120/5HR (spectral resolution < 0.02 cm-1) spectrometer performs regular NDACC and XCO2 TCCON-like measurements using alternate optical components and retrieval strategies but producing similar results. Two low-resolution portable EM27/SUN (spectral resolution < 0.5 cm-1) FTIR instruments are permanently operated at the university campus (UNAM) South of the city, and at a northern site (Vallejo) since 2016 and 2019, respectively. The other 4 EM27/SUN instruments were deployed as part of the MERCI-CO2 project. The measurement campaign was funded by the CONACyT-ANR project 290589 ‘Mexico City’s Regional Carbon Impacts’ (ANR-17-CE04-0013-01).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: One month of high temporal resolution observations of atmospheric pollutants in a Mediterranean port.

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: One month of high temporal resolution observations of atmospheric pollutants in a Mediterranean port.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: In the summer of 2021, a comprehensive measurement campaign was conducted in the Mediterranean port of Marseille (France), as part of the project PAREA (grant No 1966C0015) », supported by the French Agency for Ecological Transition (ADEME). The main objective of this campaign was to enhance knowledges about pollutant emissions from shipping. High-temporal-resolution data were simultaneously collected from two monitoring sites implemented in the port vicinity to provide the chemical composition of ship emissions in both the gas and the particulate phases. The sites were selected to capture ship emissions specifically while minimizing influence from other sources. The project repository contains time series of pollutants concentrations in ambient air from a large set of instruments. Data has been validated following quality insurance procedures.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Observed and corrected precipitation at Ny-Alesund

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Observed and corrected precipitation at Ny-Alesund

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This file contains precipitation data for Ny-Alesund from 01/01/1975 to 31/12/2022. It contains observed data downloaded from the database of the Norwegian Meteorological Institute accesible via https://seklima.met.no/ (last accessed on 20/12/2023). The corrected data correspond to the data described in O. Champagne et al., Artificial Trends or Real Changes? Investigating Precipitation Records in Ny-Ålesund, Svalbard, Journal of Hydrometeorology, DOI JHM-D-23-0182.1, 2024 (Preprint available here: https://journals.ametsoc.org/view/journals/hydr/aop/JHM-D-23-0182.1/JHM-D-23-0182.1.xml). It includes precipitation separated in rain and snow corrected using 11 different methods as well as the ensemble mean, all described in the manuscript.
The columns represent the following data: 1. Date+time [UTC]: Date and time in UTC (dd/mm/yyyy hh:mm:ss) of the collection of the precipitation, i.e. the indicated precipitation values correspond to the precipitation collected in the following 12h period 2. Observed rain: observed liquid precipitation in mm, derived from observed total precipitation as a function of temperature and solid to total precipiation ratios as described in Champagne et al. 3. Forland Ny Alesund rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Hanssen-Bauer, I., et al., 1996: Measured and true precipitations at Svalbard, DNMI Report Nr. 31/96, Norwegian Meteorological Institute, Oslo, Norway. 4. Forland Norwegian rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Forland, E. J., et al., 1996: Manual for operational correction of Nordic precipitation data, DNMI Report Nr. 24/96, Norwegian Meteorological Institute, Oslo, Norway. 5. Adam rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Adam, J. C., and D. P. Lettenmaier, 2003: Adjustment of global gridded precipitation for systematic bias: GLOBAL GRIDDED PRECIPITATION. J. Geophys. Res., 108, https://doi.org/10.1029/2002JD002499 (unchanged compared to observed precipitation). 6. Wolff wind 2m rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Wolff, M. A., et al., 2015: Derivation of a new continuous adjustment function for correcting wind induced loss of solid precipitation: results of a Norwegian field study. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 19, 951–967, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-19-951-2015. 7. Wolff wind 10m rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Wolff, M. A., et al., 2015: Derivation of a new continuous adjustment function for correcting wind induced loss of solid precipitation: results of a Norwegian field study. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 19, 951–967, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-19-951-2015. 8. Kochendorfer wind 2m rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017. 9. Kochendorfer wind 10m rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017. 10. Kochendorfer bis wind 2m rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017 (unchanged compared to observed precipitation). 11. Kochendorfer bis wind 10m rain: corrected liquid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017 (unchanged compared to observed precipitation). 12. Ensemble mean rain: Average of all corrected liquid precipitation in mm. 13. Observed snow: observed solid precipitation in mm, derived from observed total precipitation as a function of temperature and solid to total precipiation ratios as described in Champagne et al. 14. Forland Ny Alesund snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Hanssen-Bauer, I., et al., 1996: Measured and true precipitations at Svalbard, DNMI Report Nr. 31/96, Norwegian Meteorological Institute, Oslo, Norway. 15. Forland Norwegian snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Forland, E. J., et al., 1996: Manual for operational correction of Nordic precipitation data, DNMI Report Nr. 24/96, Norwegian Meteorological Institute, Oslo, Norway. 16. Adam snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Adam, J. C., and D. P. Lettenmaier, 2003: Adjustment of global gridded precipitation for systematic bias: GLOBAL GRIDDED PRECIPITATION. J. Geophys. Res., 108, https://doi.org/10.1029/2002JD002499. 17. Wolff wind 2m snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Wolff, M. A., et al., 2015: Derivation of a new continuous adjustment function for correcting wind induced loss of solid precipitation: results of a Norwegian field study. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 19, 951–967, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-19-951-2015. 18. Wolff wind 10m snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Wolff, M. A., et al., 2015: Derivation of a new continuous adjustment function for correcting wind induced loss of solid precipitation: results of a Norwegian field study. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 19, 951–967, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-19-951-2015. 19. Kochendorfer wind 2m snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017. 20. Kochendorfer wind 10m snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017. 21. Kochendorfer bis wind 2m snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017. 22. Kochendorfer bis wind 10m snow: corrected solid precipitation in mm according to Kochendorfer, J., et al., 2017: Analysis of single-Alter-shielded and unshielded measurements of mixed and solid precipitation from WMO-SPICE. Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 3525–3542, https://doi.org/10.5194/hess-21-3525-2017. 23. Ensemble mean snow: Average of all corrected solid precipitation in mm.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Analysis of the spatiotemporal evolution of the Maurienne swarm (French Alps) based on earthquake clustering. Earth and Space Science, 9, e2021EA002097.

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Analysis of the spatiotemporal evolution of the Maurienne swarm (French Alps) based on earthquake clustering. Earth and Space Science, 9, e2021EA002097.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Between August 2017 and March 2019, an intense seismic swarm was recorded in the Maurienne valley in the north of the Belledonne massif (Western French Alps). In order to study the spatiotemporal evolution of the Maurienne swarm, we created a high-resolution catalog based on template matching, double-difference relocation, and moment magnitudes. The catalog includes 71,064 events with a maximum moment magnitude of 3.5 and a magnitude of completeness of 0.7. The seismic activity is interpreted as the reactivation of an N80 strike-slip fault system called Fond de France. Moreover, earthquake relocation reveals the presence of a shallower fault system with the same strike, but opposite dip direction and smaller size. The presence of two distinct fault systems may explain the observed variation of the b-value with depth. The seismicity migrated asymmetrically in all directions during the course of about 15 months. Shorter migrations lasting 2–3 days are also observed. The different migration patterns suggest that the swarm is driven by several mechanisms, possibly pore-pressure diffusion, aseismic slip, and earthquake interactions.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Cloudy/clear-sky partitions, aerosols and surface solar irradiance measurements in Lille (Northern France) from 2010 to 2022

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Cloudy/clear-sky partitions, aerosols and surface solar irradiance measurements in Lille (Northern France) from 2010 to 2022

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The variability of solar radiation incident at the surface, vital for ecosystems and life, has also important implications for practical applications such as solar power generation. Atmospheric conditions, especially clouds and aerosols largely influence the surface solar irradiance amount and evolution, as well as its repartition into direct and diffuse components. Here we analyze coincident daytime ground-based measurements of level 2.0 aerosol optical properties from AERONET photometer and of direct and diffuse horizontal surface irradiances from a set of pyrheliometer and pyranometer in operation at the ATOLL (Atmospheric Observations in LiLle) platform in north of France over the period 2010-2022. In order to isolate the radiative effect of aerosols from that of cloud, a separation between cloudy-sun, clear-sun with surrounding clouds and clear-sky moments is performed using two cloud detection algorithms at 1-min resolution.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: DAS-BIGORRE-2022: Fiber-Optics Distributed Acoustic Sensing records (Bigorre, Hautes-Pyrénées, France)

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: DAS-BIGORRE-2022: Fiber-Optics Distributed Acoustic Sensing records (Bigorre, Hautes-Pyrénées, France)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset consists of Distributed Acoustic Sensing observations recorded along a 91-km fiber optics cable in Bigorre (Hautes-Pyrénées, France) between 2022-08-31 and 2022-09-20. The dataset contains 19x 10-minutes records of strain rate data; each subset contains a seismic event (13 earthquakes, 6 quarry blasts) of known magnitude and epicenter location calculated by the BCSF-RENASS service. We also include a kml file containing fiber location coordinates.
The dataset is associated with the scientific publication: C. Huynh, Hibert C., Jestin C., Malet J.-P., Lanticq V. 2024. A real scale application of a novel set of spatial and similarity features for detection and classification of natural seismic sources from Distributed Acoustic Sensing data. Geophysical Journal International (GJI).
Read the readme.md file for details of file contents.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Thermal circulation detection by the methods developed by Hulin et al., 2019 and applied to the present study by Gueffier et al.

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Thermal circulation detection by the methods developed by Hulin et al., 2019 and applied to the present study by Gueffier et al.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This archive contains datasets and R scripts to carry out the 3 detection methods previously proposed by Hulin et al., JAMC, 2019.
- HulinEtalThermalCirculationDetectionMethod1.R: R script to carry out Method 1. Result in output file OutputMethod1.txt - HulinEtalThermalCirculationDetectionMethod2.R: R script to carry out Method 2. Result in output file OutputMethod2.csv - InputWindDataForHulinMethods1-2.csv: input data file common to Methods 1 and 2.
Method 3 needs HourlyDataset.csv as input data file. HulinEtalThermalCirculationDetectionMethod3.R is the master R script to carry out the method, calling successively the following subroutines: 01_spechum_daily_anomaly.R 02_spechum_anabatic_ranking.R 03_spechum_reordering_all_data.R 04_anabatic_spechum.R

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Volcanic Sulfur Dioxide emissions from Sentinel-5P/TROPOMI (Etna and Piton de la Fournaise)

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Volcanic Sulfur Dioxide emissions from Sentinel-5P/TROPOMI (Etna and Piton de la Fournaise)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This repository contains multi-year time-series of volcanic sulfur dioxide (SO2) emission rates released by Etna and Piton de la Fournaise volcanoes. The emission rates are estimated from measurements of the TROPOMI sensor onboard of the Sentinel-5-Precursor (Sentinel-5P) satellite. Emission rates are computed from SO2 mass burdens extracted from the TROPOMI images, using the "disk method" described in the Grandin et al. (2023) publication.
This dataset contains files that can be used for replicating results for the two cases studied in the publication: * Piton de la Fournaise (2021-2023) * Etna (2021)
The dataset contains input and output data for the "SO2 Flux Calculator" algorithm, which is available as : * a command-line tool: https://git.icare.univ-lille.fr/icare-public/so2-flux-calculator * an on-demand interactive web app: https://dataviz.icare.univ-lille.fr/so2-flux-calculator
Acknowledgements: * The web-based VolcPlume Platform was used for satellite and ground-based multi-station analysis (https://www.icare.univ-lille.fr/volcplume) * Facilities of the European Space Agency (ESA) were used for access to Sentinel-5P TROPOMI Level 2 SO2 products (https://documentation.dataspace.copernicus.eu/Data/SentinelMissions/Sentinel5P.html#sentinel-5p-level-2-sulfur-dioxide) * Facilities of the Copernicus Climate Change Service Climate Data Store (CDS) were used for access to European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) ERA-5 global reanalysis (https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp)
Support from AERIS/ICARE (Atmosphere Data and Services centre) for the co-development of the VolcPlume Platform, is acknowledged. This project is also supported by FormaTerre (Solid Earth Data and Service centre), and by the ``Data Terra'' Research Infrastructure. The research was supported by funding from Horizon Europe FAIR-EASE project (grant No. 101058785) and CaPPA Labex (Agence Nationale de la Recherche No. ANR-11-LABX-0005-0).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Linear dune orientation in Antarctica

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Linear snow dunes are eolian bedforms with a wide range of sizes (10-10³m long; 0.1-1m high) which are similar to those found in sand deserts and on other planets. This dataset provides the orientation of hectometer linear (>30m-1km) snow dunes in Antarctica with Sentinel-2 and Landsat-8 images (respectively 10m and 15m resolution) at 25km resolution. The dataset also includes the elongating and bed-instability mode orientations. They are obtained using the theory developed for sand dunes by Courrech et al. 2014, DOI:10.1130/G35657.1. This theory shows that for the same wind regime, two different dune orientation (bed-instability and elongating) can exist depending on the sediment availability. The elongating and bed-instability mode orientations derived from ERA-5 reanalysis at ERA-5 Reanalysis resolution (0.25°x0.25°)

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: High-resolution co-seismic fault offsets and rupture traces of the 2023 Türkiye earthquakes using satellite imagery (Sentinel-2)

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: High-resolution co-seismic fault offsets and rupture traces of the 2023 Türkiye earthquakes using satellite imagery (Sentinel-2)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: On February 6, 2023, southern Türkiye was struck by two large earthquakes at 01:17 UTC (Mw=7.8, Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş) and 10:30 UTC (Mw=7.6, Elbistan, Kahramanmaraş), causing severe damage at the complex junction of the Dead Sea Fault (DSF), the Cyprus Arc and the East Anatolian Fault Zone (EAFZ). The ruptures propagated along several known strands of the southwestern termination of the EAFZ, the main Pazarcık and Karasu valley faults, and the Çardak-Sürgü fault. Here we present the high-resolution mapping of the entire coseismic surface rupture and an estimate of the rupture width, total and on-fault offset, and diffuse deformation for the two mainshocks. The mapping is derived from image correlation of Sentinel-2 optical satellite imagery and validated with offset measurements collected on the ground. We find that the ruptures extend over lengths of 310 km and 140 km for the Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.6 mainshocks, respectively. The maximum offsets reach 7.5 ± 0.8 m and 8.7 ± 0.8 m near the epicenters of the Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.6 events, respectively.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Strength of TROPOMI Satellite Observations in Retrieving Hourly Resolved Sources of Volcanic Sulfur Dioxide by Inverse Modeling

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Strength of TROPOMI Satellite Observations in Retrieving Hourly Resolved Sources of Volcanic Sulfur Dioxide by Inverse Modeling

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Volcanic eruptions release sulfur dioxide (SO2) gas, affecting air quality, ecosystems, aviation, and potentially climate. To comprehensively assess these atmospheric effects as well as local volcanic hazards, high-temporal-resolution information on SO2 mass flux and injection height is crucial and can be delivered on an hourly basis by inverse modeling. We show here the strength of assimilating high-spatial-resolution SO2 column measurements from Sentinel-5P/TROPOMI hyperspectral observations, compared to coarser resolution Suomi-NPP/OMPS data, through inverse modeling using the CHIMERE Eulerian chemistry-transport model. As a case study, we investigate the dynamics of the 2018 Ambrym eruption (December 13–18, Vanuatu) starting with the extrusion of an intra-caldera lava flow, coinciding with lava lake draining, followed by the lateral propagation of a voluminous intrusion of magma triggering a submarine eruption. Prior to this eruption marking the end of a decades-long sustained passive degassing associated to lava lake activity, Ambrym held the distinction of top ranking volcanic SO2 emitters in the world. The assimilation of TROPOMI data by inverse modeling proves efficient for accurately characterizing Ambrym SO2 emissions during periods of intense degassing that can be strongly underestimated with OMPS data. We show that this advantage relies on the high spatial resolution of TROPOMI observations which allows for robustly capturing near-source highly concentrated SO2 plumes emitted a few hours before satellite overpass. TROPOMI measurements, also facilitate the detection of volcanic SO2 even at the noisy swath edges, thanks to a superior signal-to-noise ratio and less pixel geometric distortion than OMPS. This distinctive attribute of TROPOMI has enabled the characterization of pre-eruptive SO2 emissions missed by OMPS. Moreover, our inverse modeling procedure effectively discerns, and traces hidden SO2 plumes beneath clouds by assimilating SO2 column data from successive satellite overpasses, hence mitigating satellite retrieval limitations. Furthermore, this approach proves to be less susceptible to interference from ash emissions, as compared to flux estimation derived from near-source observations by the geostationary Himawari-8/AHI sensor. Our study unveils that the 2018 Ambrym eruption discharged approximately 42 +/-16 kt (by OMPS) to 52+/-13 kt (by TROPOMI) of SO2 during the event. The hourly-resolved SO2 flux time series retrieved by inverse modeling sheds light on the eruption’s progression, pinpointing distinct sources of SO2 emissions from either lava flow or shallow magma intrusions. In summary, the assimilation of TROPOMI data into inverse modeling procedures holds substantial promise for advancing our comprehension of magma transport and the environmental repercussions associated with volcanic eruptions.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Year-round daily Meteopole-Flux weather, energy, carbon and soil-plant variables

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Year-round daily Meteopole-Flux weather, energy, carbon and soil-plant variables

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Since 2012, Meteo-France has been measuring meteorological variables, energy, carbon and water fluxes, as well as soil moisture and soil temperature at various depths at its Meteopole site in Toulouse. This is a daily subset from 2016 to 2022 of the full half-hourly database available on the ACTRIS and ICOS (FR-Tou site) portals, including infrared land surface temperature and leaf area index derived from a sunphotometer. In this subset, the observations are close to solar noon.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Ground measurements of surface solar irradiance, aerosol optical properties and sky conditions estimates in Lille (North of France) over the period 2010-2022

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Ground measurements of surface solar irradiance, aerosol optical properties and sky conditions estimates in Lille (North of France) over the period 2010-2022

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
Ground measurements from the ATOLL (Atmospheric Observations in LiLLE, https://www.loa.univ-lille.fr/observations/plateformes.html?p=lille) platform in Villeneuve-d'Ascq (North of France) over the period 2010-2022.
Detail of available columns: -date: Date and time of the measurement (UTC, format: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss) - UTC: Decimal time of day in hours associated to the measurement (UTC) - GHI: Global Horizontal Irradiance (W/m²) - DNI: Direct Normal Irradiance (W/m²) - BHI: Beam Horizontal Irradiance (W/m²) - DHI: Diffuse Horizontal irradiance (W/m²) - SZA: Computed Solar Zenith Angle (°) - cosineSZA: Cosine of the SZA - clear_sky_flag: Boolean (True: Sky clear of clouds; False: Presence of clouds in the sky) - clear_sun flag: Boolean (True: Sun direction clear of clouds; False: Cloud present between the instruments and the Sun) - cloudy_sun_flag: Boolean (opposite of clear_sun_flag) - clear_sun_with_clouds_flag: Boolean (True: Presence of clouds in the sky but not in the direction of the Sun; False: Cloud present between the instruments and the Sun) - AOD_550nm: Aerosol Optical Depth at 550nm - AOD_440nm: Aerosol Optical Depth at 440nm - 440-870_Angstrom_Exponent: Angström Exponent between 440 and 870 nm - aer_class_flag: Aerosol class associated to the measured aerosol optical properties (Continental, Continental polluted, Mixed, Maritime, Desert dusts or Strong events) - Precipitable_Water(cm): Integrated precipitable water vapor content in the direction of the Sun (cm) - Ozone(Dobson): Ozone content (Dobson units)
Irradiance measurements of DNI and DHI are performed routinely at a 1-minute resolution by a set of a pyrheliometer (Kipp & Zonen CHP1) and a pyranometer (Kipp & Zonen CMP22) placed on a sun tracking device. BHI is computed as BHI = DNI*cos(SZA) GHI is computed as GHI = BHI + DHI
Quality checks were applied following the recommendations from the BSRN network (https://bsrn.awi.de/fileadmin/user_upload/bsrn.awi.de/Publications/BSRN_recommended_QC_tests_V2.pdf). Only "Physically Possible Limits" and "Extremely Rare Limits" were checked as GHI and BHI/DHI measurements are not independent.
Measurements are reported between sunrise + 30 minutes and sunset - 30 minutes to maximize the performances of the cloud-screening methods.
The method described in Batlles et al. (2000, 10.1016/0038-092X(90)90055-H) is used to isolate clear-sun (no clouds in the direction of the Sun) moments from cloudy-sun (clouds in the direction of the Sun). A modified version of the algorithm from Garcia et al. (2014, DOI:10.1002/2013JD020301) is used to distinguish clear-sun conditions between clear-sky (no clouds in the sky) moments and clear-sun with clouds situations (clouds present in the sky but not in the direction of the Sun).
Note: The first five measurements of each hour were also removed for long term consistency, as instrumental problems prevented the acquisition of data at such times before the year 2020.
//
Photometric measurements (aerosol optical depth, angström exponent, precipitable water vapor and ozone contents) are performed as part of the AERONET-PHOTONS network and are directly available here: https://aeronet.gsfc.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/data_display_aod_v3?site=Lille&nachal=2&level=1
Level 2.0 data is reported here from 2010 to July 2022 and level 1.5 data thereafter due to data availability.
Aerosol Optical Depth at 550nm was computed following the methodology described by Gueymard et al. (2020, DOI:10.1016/j.atmosenv.2019.117216).
The aerosol class flag presents an estimate of the aerosol optical properties class based on AOD [440nm] and Angström Exponent data as in Chesnoiu et al. 2024 (in prep.).
Note: AERONET measurements are only performed when the Sun direction is clear of clouds with a time resolution ranging from 3 minutes (after 2016) to 15 minutes (before 2016). Blank spaces (or NaN values) are reported when AERONET data is not available.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: GNSS-TEC perturbation from the 2022 Hunga Tonga volcano eruption over France

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: GNSS-TEC perturbation from the 2022 Hunga Tonga volcano eruption over France

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The 2022 Hunger Tonga volcano eruption is one of the most intense volcanic explosion that shook the whole Earth-atmosphere system. A strong pressure pulse was observed worldwide at ground level with pressure sensors and seismometers and in the upper atmosphere with GNSS sensors. This datasets focus on the first passage of the Lamb wave over France, observed using the permanent GNSS network RENAG .

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Observed and mean of corrected precipitation in Ny-Alesund

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Observed and mean of corrected precipitation in Ny-Alesund

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This file contains precipitation data for Ny-Alesund from 01/01/1975 to 31/12/2022. It contains observed data downloaded from the database of the Norwegian Meteorological Institute accessible via https://seklima.met.no/ (last accessed on 20/12/2023). The corrected data correspond to the data described in O. Champagne et al., Artificial Trends or Real Changes? Investigating Precipitation Records in Ny-Ålesund, Svalbard, Journal of Hydrometeorology, DOI JHM-D-23-0182.1, 2024 (Preprint available here: https://journals.ametsoc.org/view/journals/hydr/aop/JHM-D-23-0182.1/JHM-D-23-0182.1.xml). The file contains one table "Rain+Snow".
The columns represent the following data: 1. Date+time [UTC]: Date and time in UTC of the collection of the precipitation, i.e. the indicated values correspond to the precipitation collected in the following 12h period 2. Observed Rain: observed liquid precipitation in mm, derived from observed total precipitation as a function of temperature and solid to total precipitation ratios as described in Champagne et al. 3. Observed Snow: observed solid precipitation in mm, derived from observed total precipitation as a function of temperature and solid to total precipitation ratios as described in Champagne et al. 4. Observed Rain+Snow: observed total precipitation in mm, downloaded from seklima.met.no 5. Ensemble mean Rain: Average of all corrected liquid precipitation in mm. 6. Ensemble mean Snow: Average of all corrected solid precipitation in mm. 7. Ensemble mean Rain+Snow: Average of all corrected total precipitation in mm.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Dataset for a reduced-scale canyon street to study tree climate benefits: summer 2020 data with well-watered apple trees - V1.1

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Dataset for a reduced-scale canyon street to study tree climate benefits: summer 2020 data with well-watered apple trees - V1.1

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The dataset was acquired in an outdoor reduced-scale canyon street in Angers, France during summer 2020 to study the impact of well-watered trees on urban microclimate and human thermal comfort. The data can benefit to researchers in urban meteorology, bioclimatology and ecophysiology. It can also provide reference data to run and evaluate microclimate models, especially regarding plant-atmosphere interactions.

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: HERPIN Sophie (Institut Agro Rennes-Angers (Rennes - France)) (2024).Dataset for a reduced-scale canyon street to study tree climate benefits: summer 2020 data with well-watered apple trees - V1

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: First and previous version (V1) of the dataset. This previous version is very close to the present version. The main change is related to the fact that the former version did not have yet information on the street surfaces albedo.

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: First and previous version (V1) of the dataset. This previous version is very close to the present version. The main change is related to the fact that the former version did not have yet information on the street surfaces albedo.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Dataset produced by Institut Agro - EPHor research unit (microclimate, soil data, leaf temperature data, light interception, transpiration data) and IRHS (tree leaf area and crown dimension). The street is oriented north-south, with an aspect ratio of 1, and a reduction factor of 5. It is organized in three zones: two zones with a central alignment of 5 ornamental apple trees, and one zone without trees. The 3 zones are instrumented over the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum. The water inputs are controlled through a drip-irrigation system. The data include microclimate variables, energy fluxes, soil water status data, tree leaf temperature, tree transpiration as well as crown light interception . The trees are characterised in terms of leaf area and crown dimensions.
This is version V1.1 of the dataset, with minor modifications to metadata and addition of surface albedos, compared to first and previous version of the dataset (V1). More precisely, the minor modifications in this version are: -addition of albedo values for street ground and street walls in "./01_METADATA/Material_thermal_properties.ods" - addition of one photo in metadata file "./01_METADATA/METADATA_canyon2020.ods" -minor update on sensor metadata in file "./00_DATA/00_SOIL_VEGETAL_CLIMATE/nomenclature_canyon2020_en.ods"

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: A new high spatial density temperature dataset in the Grenoble alpine valley (France) for urban heat island investigation and climate services dedicated to municipalities purposes

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: A new high spatial density temperature dataset in the Grenoble alpine valley (France) for urban heat island investigation and climate services dedicated to municipalities purposes

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Within the study of the urban heat island (UHI) in Echirolles and Grenoble (France), two temperature measurement networks have been deployed. The aim is to measure the temperature gradients associated with the UHI in summer. The ADEME-funded CASSANDRE research program analyzes and processes these observations to study the vulnerability of inhabitants to heat waves and more generally to summer heat stress.

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Data came from urban heat island studies led by Xavier Foissard for the city of Echirolles and the city of Grenoble. A total of 62 measurement points has been installed in the various neighborhoods on 3-meter-high streetlights, starting in summer 2019. The temperature sensors were equipped with a Tinytag Talk 2 data logger (Gemini Data Loggers) protected by a solar RS3 radiation shields (ONSET). The preliminary classification of the various neighborhood typologies according to "Local Climate Zone" guided the choice of location for the temperature sensors. These urban observations respond to a dual challenge: firstly, to observe temperature located in complex topographical situations with valleys, and secondly, to observe the urban climate in neighborhoods where social considerations are important. The municipalities of Echirolles and Grenoble were involved in the investigation. Following these investigations, the work became part of the CASSANDRE research program funded by ADEME (French Agency for Ecological Transition). These data were described in detail in a data paper.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Timeseries of the snow surface temperature acquired at the Col du Lautaret (French Alps) during winter 2021-2022 with an uncooled thermal infrared camera

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Timeseries of the snow surface temperature acquired at the Col du Lautaret (French Alps) during winter 2021-2022 with an uncooled thermal infrared camera

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains maps of the surface temperature of snow acquired at the Col du Lautaret (French Alps) every 2 minutes during winter 2021-2022 with an uncooled thermal infrared camera (TIR), timeseries of RGB images of the scene acquired every 10 minutes during operation of the TIR camera, timeseries of the surface temperature acquired every 30 seconds at two distinct points in the camera’s field of view, and the TIR camera’s internal temperature.

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Maison de la Télédétection - 500 rue Jean-François Breton

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: This dataset was produced in the context of the preparation of the CNES/ISRO TRISHNA mission during a PhD co-funded by CNES (Centre National d'Études Spatiales). It contains 79563 maps of the surface temperature of snow acquired at the Col du Lautaret (45.0347 N, 6.4051 E, 2057 m a.s.l.) every 2 minutes during winter 2021-2022 with an Optris PI640i thermal infrared camera. They are singleband, and the surface temperature data is in float32 format, 464x506 pixel wide at 2 m resolution in the EPSG:32632 projection. The dataset also includes timeseries of RGB images of the scene acquired every 10 minutes during operation of the TIR camera, timeseries of the surface temperature acquired every 30 seconds at two distinct points in the camera’s field of view (AWS-North, 45.0308 N 6.3946 E, and AWS-South, 45.0335 N 6.3950) and the TIR camera’s internal temperature. Images were acquired between 2021-11-20 and 2022-05-12. The images were filtered for foggy and snowy conditions, processed radiometrically and orthoprojected on a digital elevation model. The radiometric accuracy on snow-covered soil is 1.28 K (mean absolute error). Orthoprojection accuracy is 4.3 m (median projection error). The dataset contains 24 zip files. Every file corresponds to a week of the year (starting each Monday), for example 2022_w06.zip refers to week 6 of the year 2023. Data was produced and processed by Université Grenoble-Alpes and the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS, Institut des Géosciences de l'Environnement). Data is property of the Université Grenoble-Alpes (Institut des Géosciences de l'Environnement) and the Centre National d'Études Spatiales (CNES).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Role of Mantle Drag on the Tectonics of Subduction Zones: Insights from Laboratory Models

gmd:textGroup.gmd:LocalisedCharacterString: Role of Mantle Drag on the Tectonics of Subduction Zones: Insights from Laboratory Models

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset includes videos depicting the evolution in top and lateral views of 11 analogue experiments of subduction to better understand subduction dynamics and upper-plate shortening in the context of mantle-driven oceanic subduction. For details on the experimental set-up, monitoring techniques and interpretation of the results, please refer to Geffroy et al. (2023) to which these data are supplementary material. Reference: T. Geffroy, B. Guillaume, M. Simoes, A. Replumaz, R. Lacassin, L. Husson, and J.J. Kermarrec (2023): Role of Mantle Drag on the Tectonics of Subduction Zones: Insights from Laboratory Models., Tectonics.
